items.message: The water level in the Eastern Yar is falling in Alverstone and Sandown. Today (Tuesday 10/08/21) some ponded water may continue to impact low lying land and roads adjacent to the river. Over the next 5 days, apart from the odd isolated shower, the weather should be fairly dry. Further flooding is not expected, and any residual flood impacts should cease over the next 24 hours.

items.description: Tidal Thames riverside from Putney Bridge to Teddington Weir
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex

floodArea.county: Greater London, Hammersmith and Fulham, Hounslow, Richmond upon Thames, Wandsworth

items.message:
River levels are expected to be high as a result of spring tides and recent rainfall.

The forecast high tide at Richmond is 4.65mAOD at 05:30 on Wednesday 11th August 2021.

Flooding of low-lying roads and footpaths is expected, which may exist for one to two hours either side of high tide. Flooding of properties is not expected.

We believe there is a possibility of flooding for Putney Embankment (SW15), Chiswick Mall and Strand on the Green (W4), Thames Bank at Mortlake (SW14), Ranelagh Drive (TW1), Friars Lane and Water Lane (TW9), Riverside and The Embankment at Twickenham, and the Towpath below Teddington Lock. 

Astronomical tide levels peak on this tide. The river flow at Teddington Weir is normal for this time of year at 70 cubic metres per second and is rising. We anticipate the flows to remain normal for the next couple of days.

We are closely monitoring the situation.

This message will be updated by 10:00 on Wednesday morning, or as the situation changes.

This Flood Alert has been removed. 
River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold. There is no longer a threat of flooding, though standing water and debris may still remain. 
We continue to monitor the situation. We are clearing debris from weed screens
Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels.

The River Uck has now returned to near normal along its length, following Monday morning's heavy rain. Residual flood impacts might remain in fields and on rural roads. The weather forecast predicts high pressure and no more than 1 or 2 mm of rain for the next five days. The ground is now a lot wetter than normal for the time of year. Any future rainfall events in the coming weeks are likely to generate a response from the river. We will continue to monitor the river levels and forecast and will re-issue this message if the risk of flooding could return.

The Western Rother at Fittleworth is still high, but is now slowly falling. Minor flood impacts in the area, affecting fields, gardens and rural roads, should begin to slowly ease. River levels should return to near normal in Fittleworth, by Wednesday evening 11/08/2021. In Liss and Sheet, Iping, Midhurst and Lodsbridge near Selham, river levels have already returned to normal. The weather forecast predicts high pressure and no more than 1 or 2 mm of rain for the next five days, and therefore very little flood risk in the week ahead. As a precaution though, please keep flood resilience measures in place in Fittleworth during Tuesday and Wednesday, while river levels remain high. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will update this message by 10:00 Wednesday 11/08/2021.

floodArea.county: East Sussex, Kent, Surrey, West Sussex

items.message:
This Flood Alert has been removed.  
River levels have now fallen below the level expected to cause flooding. There is no longer a threat of flooding, though standing water and debris may still remain. No further rainfall is forecast for today, Tuesday 10 August.

We will continue to monitor the situation

items.description: River Rother and its tributaries from Turks Bridge to the Royal Military Canal
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex
items.message:
This Flood Alert has been removed.
River levels have now fallen below the level expected to cause flooding, though standing water and debris may still remain. The weather forecast is dry for the next few days.  

Our incident response staff have been out on the ground checking and clearing any blockages and debris from the rivers, after this summer flood event.

The Cuckmere River is still high through Alfriston, following Monday morning's heavy rain. Minor flood impacts are expected to remain, with water in fields, on rural roads, and potentially affecting low lying areas such as North Street, Willows car park, and land near the Old Clergy House Alfriston. However, river levels in Alfriston are now slowly falling, and will continue to fall through Tuesday evening and Wednesday morning, so flood impacts should begin to slowly ease. The weather forecast predicts high pressure and no more than 1 or 2 mm of rain for the next five days. The river level in Alfriston should be much lower by Wednesday afternoon.  River levels in Hellingly are already much lower than at their peak Monday. Please plan to avoid driving through routes susceptible to flooding. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will update this message by 10:00 Wednesday 11/08/2021.

The river level has now returned to near normal, through all communities on the Upper Ouse, following Monday morning's heavy rain. Residual flood impacts might remain in fields and on rural roads. The weather forecast predicts high pressure and no more than 1 or 2 mm of rain for the next five days, and therefore very little flood risk. However, the ground is now a lot wetter than normal for the time of year. Any future rainfall events in the coming weeks are likely to generate a response from the river. We will continue to monitor the river levels and forecast and will re-issue this message if the risk of flooding could return.

The River Adur is still high, but is now falling following Monday morning's heavy rain. Flood impacts will continue to affect the A281 at Mock Bridge, near Shermanbury, nearby fields and gardens. However, flood water will slowly recede during Tuesday, with an improving outlook. The weather forecast predicts high pressure and no more than 1 or 2 mm of rain for the next five days. River levels should fall by 30 cm by Tuesday evening, and return to near normal Wednesday. While some roads could still be affected by flood water, please plan to avoid driving through routes vulnerable to flooding included in this message. The ground is now a lot wetter than normal for the time of year. Any future rainfall events in the coming weeks are likely to generate a response from the river. We will continue to monitor the river levels and forecast and will re-issue this message if the risk of flooding could return.

items.description: River Mole and its tributaries from Kinnersley Manor to South Hersham
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex
items.message:
This Flood Alert has been removed.  

River levels have now fallen below the level expected to cause flooding.  There is no longer a risk of flooding, though standing water and debris may still remain. No further rainfall is forecast for the next 48 hours.

We continue to monitor the situation, however, please remain aware of your local situation.

floodArea.county: Greater London, Hounslow, Richmond upon Thames

items.message:
The risk of flooding from the tidal River Crane has now reduced. No further flooding to fields and roads is expected. 
We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert for future high tides if necessary.
